player_decision.reason: Th9h is weak in 3-handed preflop; fold to preserve stack and wait for a better spot.
10BB effective heads-up in the small blind with J4o: too weak to raise/call a shove and high variance to jam. Limp to realize equity cheaply and keep variance low versus a random opponent.

Js5s is a marginal hand but cheap to see a flop from the big blind against a single limper. No need to inflate the pot preflop with a weak holding — check/call preserves stack and keeps options postflop.
We have an open-ended straight draw on a low, coordinated board heads-up. Semi-bluffing for about 3/4 pot applies pressure to many random holdings while building the pot for our strong draw.

I have middle pair (5s) with a decent jack kicker and a backdoor spade/straight potential. Alice’s bet is a standard c‑bet from the small blind and her range is wide. Calling (rather than raising) uses my positional advantage, keeps the pot manageable and gives me a chance to improve on the turn with correct pot odds.
We have an open-ended straight draw and the Q is a good barrel card to pressure 6x/5x. Betting half-pot builds fold equity while keeping room to fold versus a shove, since we can’t check here.

I have a marginal pair (5s) and decent pot odds to see the river (call 25 into 75). Raising or shoving over this turn bet would risk too many chips with a medium hand against a wide SB range, so call to realize equity and re-evaluate on the river.

We rivered the straight on 3-6-5-Q-7 with 4hJc. With SPR ~0.5, jamming maximizes value versus pairs/two-pairs/sets and gets called by many 4x for at least a chop; only a few combos (48/98) beat us. All-in is the highest-EV play here.

My best hand is only a single pair (5s, Jack kicker). Alice’s line (bet flop, bet turn, shove river) is polarized to stronger made hands (Qx, sets, two pair, rivered 7x) or a rare bluff. Pot odds require ~33% equity to call 50 into 150; my showdown equity is likely below that. Fold to preserve stack.
